Award.AwardTitle: BD Spokes: SPOKE: MIDWEST: Collaborative: Advanced Computational Neuroscience Network (ACNN)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Novel neuroscience tools and techniques are necessary to enable insight into the building blocks of neural circuits, the interactions between these circuits that underpin the functions of the human brain, and modulation of these circuits that affect our behavior. To leverage rapid technological development in sensing, imaging, and data analysis new ground breaking advances in neuroscience are necessary to facilitate knowledge discovery using data science methods. To address this societal grand challenge, the project will foster new interdisciplinary collaborations across computing, biological, mathematical, and behavioral science disciplines together with partnerships in academia, industry, and government at multiple levels. The Big Data Neuroscience Spoke titled Midwest: Advanced Computational Neuroscience Network (ACNN) is strongly aligned with the national priority area of neuroscience and brings together a diverse set of committed regional partners to enable the Midwest region to realize the promise of Big Data for neuroscience. The ACNN Spoke will build broad consensus on the core requirements, infrastructure, and components needed to develop a new generation of sustainable interdisciplinary Neuroscience Big Data research. ACNN will leverage the strengths and resources in the Midwest region to increase innovation and collaboration for the understanding of the structure, physiology, and function of the human brain through partnerships and services in education, tools, and best practices.

The ACNN will design, pilot and support powerful neuroscientific computational resources for high-throughput, collaborative, and service-oriented data aggregation, processing and open-reproducible science. The ACNN Spoke framework will address three specific problems related to neuroscience Big Data: (1) data capture, organization, and management involving multiple centers and research groups, (2) quality assurance, preprocessing and analysis that incorporates contextual metadata, and (3) data communication to software and hardware computational resources that can scale with the volume, velocity, and variety of neuroscience datasets. The ACNN will build a sustainable ecosystem of neuroscience community partners in both academia and industry using existing technologies for collaboration and virtual meeting together with face-to-face group meetings. The planned activities of the ACNN Spoke will also allow the Midwest Big Data Hub to disseminate additional Big Data technologies resources to the neuroscience community, including access to supercomputing facilities, best practices, and platforms.

This award received co-funding from CISE Divisions of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure (ACI) and Information and Intelligent Systems (IIS).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development and adoption of computational neuroscience tools are becoming a key component for advancing our understanding of the structure, function, and interaction of neural circuits that form the foundation of our behavior and cognition. The Advanced Computational Neuroscience Network (ACNN) project aimed to address the critical need for common data standards, reproducibility underpinned by provenance metadata, indexing of available resources, and build a community consensus for data interoperability as well as sharing. This project brings together complementary expertise in neuroscience, computing, and social science involving seven research universities across the Midwest to coordinate activities across more than 20 partner sites, including neuroimaging centers.

The ACNN project focused on three objectives of: (1) development and dissemination of neuroscience workflows using community standards in data modeling and data processing; (2) advancing efficient data sharing protocols and data analytics in neuroscience using cloud-based infrastructure; and (3) development and adoption of neuroscience ontologies, provenance metadata standards, and high performance computing. During project period, the project has successfully developed and disseminated multiple open-source neuroinformatics resources, including:

1. Neuro-integrative Connectivity (NIC) platform: The Neuro-Integrative Connectivity (NIC) platform is a new scientific workflow-based neuroinformatics tool for large-scale cohort studies to analyze brain network connectivity using high-resolution Stereotactic Electroencephalogram (SEEG) signal data. The NIC platform is built using an open-source scientific workflow system called Apache Taverna to support: (1) large-scale signal data processing; (2) computation of multiple signal-coupling measures to derive brain functional connectivity networks; and (3) computation of multiple global as well as local network analysis metrics. The NIC platform is accessible at https://bmhinformatics.case.edu/nicworkflow/accounts/login/?next=/nicworkflow/

2. MPI-LiFE: Enhanced Linear Fascicle Evaluation (LiFE) Tool with Message Passing Interface (MPI). The original LiFE tool was designed for proof-of-concept and not for high performance. For the MPI-LiFE tool, the Ohio State University team designed and developed the parallel versions of LiFE with MPI programming model with Indiana University Bloomington. The MPI-LiFE tool is publicly available on the website: http://neurohpc.cse.ohio-state.edu/.

A key contribution of the ACNN project has been the creation of a Midwest neuroscience network community through the successful organization of five annual workshops that have brought together students, trainees, research fellows, junior investigators, and industry partners (http://www.neurosciencenetwork.org/). The annual ACNN workshops have facilitated the sharing of resources, learning modules, and protocols to the wider neuroscience research community; for example, in 2019 more than 123 participants attended the workshop.
